title: The Lord’s Eternal Priesthood
shortSummary: Psalm 110 is a Messianic psalm attributed to David, proclaiming the exaltation of the Messiah who sits at God's right hand and rules with divine authority. It highlights the Messiah’s eternal priesthood after the order of Melchizedek and His victorious reign over enemies, emphasizing both His kingly and priestly roles.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The psalmist who records this prophetic psalm pointing to the coming Messiah.

keyCharacters.name: The LORD
keyCharacters.description: God the Father who speaks to 'my Lord' and establishes His reign and priesthood.

keyCharacters.name: My Lord
keyCharacters.description: The Messiah, the promised King and eternal Priest, who is seated at God's right hand.

keyCharacters.name: Melchizedek
keyCharacters.description: A mysterious priest-king from Genesis whose priesthood is eternal and serves as a type for the Messiah’s priesthood.

definitions.definition: A position of honor and authority, symbolizing power and favor from God.
A metaphor for complete subjugation of enemies under one’s rule.
A priest-king who blessed Abraham, representing an eternal priesthood distinct from the Levitical line.
A symbol of authority and power used by kings to rule and discipline.

outline.heading: The Messiah’s Exalted Position
outline.description: God the Father invites the Messiah to sit at His right hand, signifying supreme authority and victory over enemies, who will become His footstool.

outline.heading: The Messiah’s Reign and Strength
outline.description: The LORD promises to send the Messiah’s strength from Zion to rule amidst enemies, with His people willingly supporting Him in holiness and youthful vigor.

outline.heading: The Eternal Priesthood of the Messiah
outline.description: God swears an unchangeable oath establishing the Messiah as a priest forever in the order of Melchizedek, highlighting His unique and eternal priestly role.

outline.heading: The Messiah’s Victorious Judgment
outline.description: The Messiah, at God’s right hand, will execute judgment on kings and nations, defeating enemies and filling the land with the dead, demonstrating His sovereign power.

outline.heading: The Messiah’s Sustained Victory
outline.description: Though victorious, the Messiah will drink from the brook on His way, symbolizing refreshment and strength to continue His mission, resulting in lifted head and triumph.

application: Trust in Christ’s sovereign rule and rest in His victory over all spiritual enemies in your life.
Approach Jesus as both King and High Priest, relying on His eternal priesthood for forgiveness and intercession.
Live willingly and holily in submission to Christ’s authority, reflecting the beauty of holiness in your daily walk.
Take courage that Christ’s power sustains believers through trials, enabling us to stand firm and victorious.

keyVerses.text: The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool.
keyVerses.significance: This verse prophesies the Messiah’s exaltation and authority, foundational for understanding Christ’s kingship.

keyVerses.text: The LORD hath sworn, and will not repent, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals the eternal and unique priesthood of the Messiah, distinct from the Levitical priesthood.

keyVerses.text: The Lord at thy right hand shall strike through kings in the day of his wrath.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the Messiah’s power to execute judgment and defeat His enemies.
